html:
Alternative forms[edit]

  • obferō

Etymology[edit]

ob- (“towards”) +‎ ferō (“bear, carry”)

Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈof.fe.roː/, [ˈɔf.fɛ.roː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈof.fe.ro/, [ˈɔf.fɛ.rɔ]

Verb[edit]

offerō (present infinitive offerre, perfect active obtulī, supine oblātum); third conjugation, irregular

  1. I bring before or bring to, present, offer, show, place before, exhibit.
  2. I expose.
  3. I cause, occasion, bestow, inflict.
  4. (Ecclesiastical Latin) I offer to God, consecrate, dedicate.
  5. (Ecclesiastical Latin) I offer up, sacrifice.

  • oblātīvus

Descendants[edit]

  • Asturian: ofrecer, ufrir
  • Catalan: oferir
  • Dutch: offeren
  • Old English: offrian
  • English: offer
  • Finnish: uhri
  • French: offrir
  • Friulian: ufrî
  • Galician: ofrecer
  • Italian: offrire
  • Norman: offri (Jersey)
  • Occitan: ofrir
  • Portuguese: oferecer, ofertar (by extension)
  • Romanian: oferi
  • Romansch: offrir, offerir, ofrir, offereir
  • Sardinian: oferrere, oferri, oferriri
  • Sicilian: uffriri, offriri
  • Spanish: ofrecer
  • Venetian: ofrir

References[edit]

  • offero in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • offero in Charlton T. Lewis (1891) An Elementary Latin Dictionary, New York: Harper & Brothers
  • offero in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
  • Carl Meissner; Henry William Auden (1894) Latin Phrase-Book‎[1], London: Macmillan and Co.
    • to sacrifice oneself for one's country: se morti offerre pro salute patriae
    • a favourable[1] opportunity presents itself: occasio datur, offertur
    • to expose oneself to peril: periculis se offerre
    • to risk one's life: salutem, vitam suam in discrimen offerre (not exponere)
